title: Can we make the Dragons more interactive?
body:
It kinda just seeing them do the same attack. It would be nice to see them actually fly around the little dragon pit, switch up their attack and maybe have a super move?

- I would love to see the fire dragon fly and sit on a cliff and let out a a continuous breath of fire(kinda like you the poro king). 
- I would like to see the Air Drake create tornadoes that spin enemies around. 
- Have the Earth drake fly up and slam back down creating tremors that knocks up enemies. 
- The water dragon would make whirlpools that slow the enemy

replies.body:
I actually love the sounds of these ideas - it would add a certain spice to the encounter that certainly doesn't exist atm. Sadly when we did the elemental drakes, one of the problems we ran into was memory usage. Because League has to be able to run on relatively low spec machines, we have a limit on how much memory we can use for an individual game of League because your computer has to load in all of the assets that will be in the game (this is what's happening during the load screen after people have chosen their models/skins). Adding unique animations, particles, audio etc, would make elemental dragons considerably more "expensive" from a performance perspective, and would mean older machines would likely have a harder time running the game. 

We might have more room now in the game than we did back then to add some more stuff like this, but we usually default to keep memory usage as low as possible rather than hit our cap so that as many players can enjoy League as possible. It's a really cool idea though! I hope we're able to do something like it some day.

A few ideas that could fit the criteria of same animation and just changing effects and particles could be something like:

Extra Ability w/ same animation (probably something like a cone range or maybe a full 180 degrees in front of the dragon):
    Cloud: Knock back, maybe summon twisters like some camps in HotS?
    Infernal: Set area on fire with DoT damage (similar to Red Buff) and maybe a sunfire effect?
    Ocean: AoE Slow, ability like {{champion:267}}  ebb and flow or bubble? 
    Mountain: Knock up (look like a {{champion:163}} skill if you can reuse assets to reduce costs and/or maybe a randuin's effect?
    Elder: Rotates between all other 4 effects (maybe in the order they spawned?)

What I had in mind was all dragons having the same wind-up animation for their abilities and the same area of effect if it helps with memory consumption. If you'd rather keep it simple we could also explore changing the initial first agro skill.

Keeping the pit wide first agro attack:
    Cloud: Knock back (how it is), maybe periodic?
    Infernal: AoE fire skill with initial damage (like a {{item:3077}} ) around the dragon and burning damage (like {{item:3068}}  that's pit wide
    Ocean: AoE slow that covers the pit
    Mountain: Slower attack speed inside the pit? Explained by tremors in the pit?
    Elder: Periodically switch between the other 4 abilities or something huge like instead of the skill only on the first agro, it triggers periodically around the elder dragon as long as they're alive?

With these ability changes in mind rewards for each dragon may have to change depending on how difficult they would make the fight to actually make the trouble worth it. If the listed skills were considered they would definitely need to be close to some kind of skill shot that could be dodged if soloing but difficult if being collapsed on in order to keep the rewards the same. Also reference to champion abilities and items for the sake of saving costs of coding, asset creation, memory consumtion, etc.

Let me know what you think! Id love some feed back and to possibly pass a few more iterations your way.

Approximately what percent of a match's asset memory usage do the current elemental drakes require, and would you consider that amount justified relative to alternatives? As much as I love the potential in elemental drakes having unique fighting styles based on their affinity, currently their differences are so minute they're sometimes difficult to notice (Ocean Drake's slow can be felt, but Cloud and Infernal Drake are only differentiated by their AD/AS values), and from this post, their individual memory usage is disproportionately high compared to that kind of diversity. If you could go back, would you do them differently?

Can't recall how large they were off hand tbh. We ended up making them as similar as possible (same model just with different textures) and recolored particles for their auto attacks because it was roughly as much as we felt responsible adding in. If we were to go back I'd say that it would have been great to have started the project long before it needed to ship to get the chance to optimise the dragons themselves, but also the game in order to get us the room we needed to make them cooler. When we were working on them it ended up coming pretty down to the wire, so the focus was almost entirely getting them down under budget as opposed to making the encounters as cool as possible. Alas the pitfalls of game development :\

That's fair, games and game features rarely turn out perfect when it comes to implementing them in practice, and looking back at what could've been done differently. From what I understand, the roster updates were also particularly intense, given the sheer number of features and systems being changed at once over a relatively short development period. With that in mind, are there plans to work on the drakes in the near future? If the main problem is memory usage, how costly would it be to, say, recycle their animation where they take flight/push everyone back, incorporate that as an AoE and attach some element-related proc? Currently, the drakes have two combat moves, namely their AoE knockback and their basic attack, but the first one is generally only applied once in the entire fight: would there be value in making it more present if it could offer more potential for differentiation and variety in fighting the drakes?

Even as you say, "wish it was more so". Dragons already have some interactivity between DPS or AOE or Tankiness or Slows but they can have more. Baron has some telegraphed attacks and CC but not enough to necessarily _demand_ interaction despite his appearance as a raid boss. The Rift Herald however, especially if you want to solo it, _demands_ interactivity out of the players to take it down the most efficiently. The Dragons and Baron are effectively the Raid Bosses of the Rift ignoring stuff like Nasus or Cho'Gath, but they're underselling right now. Both of us want more.
